raw_message: To answer my own question, template resolution works inside app, and dummy/app with the latter taking precedence. My confusion was due to the fact "ember serve" was itself confused by my experimenting with creating and deleting "templates/components" directories while it was running. Restarting it yielded the correct behavior.
message: To answer my own question, template resolution works inside app, and dummy/app with the latter taking precedence. My confusion was due to the fact "ember serve" was itself confused by my experimenting with creating and deleting "templates/components" directories while it was running. Restarting it yielded the correct behavior.

raw_message: Thanks for a great writeup. Taking a look into ember-off-canvas-components I notice there is some duplication in hbs templates across addon, app, and dummy. Where are templates supposed to go? I tried developing a test component, but its template won't be resolved unless placed in dummy/app/templates/components/. Is this to say templates should always be provided by the importing application?
message: Thanks for a great writeup. Taking a look into ember-off-canvas-components I notice there is some duplication in hbs templates across addon, app, and dummy. Where are templates supposed to go? I tried developing a test component, but its template won't be resolved unless placed in dummy/app/templates/components/. raw_message: My only problem with this approach (acceptance testing) is that now your tests are inevitably *tied* to the markup.  I'm looking into the alternative: controller testing, and it's proving to be far more difficult than imagined, as the Ember Testing framework does not provide helpers for accessing pages (routes) outside of an acceptance test.  If this is currently the only way to test CRUD operations against a REST API, I'm quite disappointed.
message: My only problem with this approach (acceptance testing) is that now your tests are inevitably *tied* to the markup. I'm looking into the alternative: controller testing, and it's proving to be far more difficult than imagined, as the Ember Testing framework does not provide helpers for accessing pages (routes) outside of an acceptance test. If this is currently the only way to test CRUD operations against a REST API, I'm quite disappointed.

A context must be given to transitionTo() / intermediateTransitionTo() when wildcard routes are used. To work I do this :

this.transitionTo('/not-found', 'not-found');

Thanks for your post :)

raw_message: I use `intermediateTransitionTo` so the invalid URL remains in the address bar.
message: I use `intermediateTransitionTo` so the invalid URL remains in the address bar.

raw_message:
Hi Pixelhandler, thanks for your blog on showing 404 page in Ember Application. 


In my application I use jQuery2.0 version. When the application is loaded in IE < 9 versions I need to show a page like "You are viewing in an unsupported browser.", 


I can use browser check and include jQuery 1.0 version in case of IE < 9, but I dont want to maintain two version of jQuery. We support latest version of IE 9+.


Can you suggest how can I handle the above scenario.
message:
Hi Pixelhandler, thanks for your blog on showing 404 page in Ember Application.

In my application I use jQuery2.0 version. When the application is loaded in IE < 9 versions I need to show a page like "You are viewing in an unsupported browser.",

I can use browser check and include jQuery 1.0 version in case of IE < 9, but I dont want to maintain two version of jQuery. We support latest version of IE 9+.

Can you suggest how can I handle the above scenario.

author.about: Co-founder of Cerebris. Developer of Syncd.com and IOUmate.com. Open source enthusiast.
author.name: Dan Gebhardt

raw_message:
Bill - thanks so much for sharing your work with Orbit!

Believe it or not, I have yet to blog about Orbit myself. I've been putting it off while I work on the code itself and a proper site with docs and guides (coming soon: orbitjs.com).

Nice work with the SocketSource, which really fills a hole in Orbit's list of available sources. I've been planning to set up a template project for sources to make it easy to test/build/distribute them individually. Please let me know if you're interested in extracting your source into a separate repo for easier maintenance and sharing.
message:
Bill - thanks so much for sharing your work with Orbit!

Believe it or not, I have yet to blog about Orbit myself. I've been putting it off while I work on the code itself and a proper site with docs and guides (coming soon: orbitjs.com).

Nice work with the SocketSource, which really fills a hole in Orbit's list of available sources. I've been planning to set up a template project for sources to make it easy to test/build/distribute them individually. Please let me know if you're interested in extracting your source into a separate repo for easier maintenance and sharing.

author.about: Developer (hacker), into JavaScript, Ember.js and Ruby on Rails
author.name: Bill Heaton

media.description: I didn't jump in head first initially because I was still trying to use jasmine for everything and felt the switch to QUnit would be painful (shows how little I knew about either framework). But after I spent some time unit testing ember.js components with QUnit, I started playing around with the ember-testing package and now I can't say enough good things about it.
media.title: ParadigmShift - Integration testing your ember.js app with QUnit and Karma

raw_message: Checkout http://toranbillups.com/blog/archive/2013/07/21/Integration-testing-your-emberjs-app-with-QUnit-and-Karma/ and using http://karma-runner.github.io
message: Checkout http://toranbillups.com/blog/a... and using http://karma-runner.github.io

raw_message:
Gotcha. I saw from this article that you tried pavlov. What was the pitfall there that caused you to use straight qunit? 


I'm finding it hard to make myself take the jump into Qunit since I already have Jasmine tests on my vanilla JS and Qunit doesn't seem to support running from the command line.  So I'm just trying to understand my options. Thanks for the help.
message:
Gotcha. I saw from this article that you tried pavlov. What was the pitfall there that caused you to use straight qunit?

I'm finding it hard to make myself take the jump into Qunit since I already have Jasmine tests on my vanilla JS and Qunit doesn't seem to support running from the command line. So I'm just trying to understand my options. Thanks for the help.

author.about: Developer (hacker), into JavaScript, Ember.js and Ruby on Rails
author.name: Bill Heaton

raw_message: @Gowiem:disqus  that reference for a Jasmine adapter was only pseudo code. QUnit has better async support in my opinion than Jasmine or Mocha, it provides `stop` and `start` methods that are very hard to simulate in an adapter for other test frameworks aside from QUnit. Also since Ember proper uses QUnit there are many examples of testing Ember, so I gave up the fight for my favorite BDD test framework Jasmine and just use QUnit for Ember apps.
message: Gowiem that reference for a Jasmine adapter was only pseudo code. QUnit has better async support in my opinion than Jasmine or Mocha, it provides `stop` and `start` methods that are very hard to simulate in an adapter for other test frameworks aside from QUnit. Also since Ember proper uses QUnit there are many examples of testing Ember, so I gave up the fight for my favorite BDD test framework Jasmine and just use QUnit for Ember apps.

media.description: stop() and start() assume QUnit. Not relying on them makes ember testing framework agnostic.
media.title: ember.js

raw_message: @pixelhandler:disqus  I know this post is a couple months old, but I was wondering what were the complications you ran into with testing with Jasmine? I saw you posted a Jasmine Adapter here: https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/pull/2626#issuecomment-17563616 and I'm wondering how that worked out.
message: Bill Heaton I know this post is a couple months old, but I was wondering what were the complications you ran into with testing with Jasmine? I saw you posted a Jasmine Adapter here: https://github.com/emberjs/emb... and I'm wondering how that worked out.

raw_message:
Great article and really helped me get feel for testing. One thing I'm left wondering, though, would this scoring code actually work? seems like it will wrongly think you rolled a strike if you roll zero then 10 in one frame. and it will wrongly think you rolled a spare if you have back-to-back rolls from different frames that add up to 10 (for example you roll 5 pins on roll 2, and 5 pins on roll 3). I noticed that neither of these things happen in your final test. 


I know that's beside the point of the article but it just made me curious. Thanks again for the write-up!
message:
Great article and really helped me get feel for testing. One thing I'm left wondering, though, would this scoring code actually work? seems like it will wrongly think you rolled a strike if you roll zero then 10 in one frame. and it will wrongly think you rolled a spare if you have back-to-back rolls from different frames that add up to 10 (for example you roll 5 pins on roll 2, and 5 pins on roll 3). I noticed that neither of these things happen in your final test.

I know that's beside the point of the article but it just made me curious. Thanks again for the write-up!

raw_message:
This is still a great tutorial for building RESTful APIs for Node.  It's got some real good fundamentals in here and goes into realistic detail about stuff you need to worry about as far as Node specifics and basics, as well as those of Express.

Spectacular job, thanks!
message:
This is still a great tutorial for building RESTful APIs for Node. It's got some real good fundamentals in here and goes into realistic detail about stuff you need to worry about as far as Node specifics and basics, as well as those of Express.

Spectacular job, thanks!

To edit and delete actions I added:
if(product === undefined) return res.send(404);

right after the findById call to deal with invalid product calls and

for get all and get one product calls I modified

return console.log(err)' to

console.log(err);
return res.send(404);

to deal with invalid product calls.

raw_message:
Hey there Bill, very nice article - thanks for sharing. I've done the infamous BG kata in php and Java but I guess I'll have to try it out in JS huh!

So I've looked at getting the whole require.js thing working with yeoman and found that I was able to do this without either the symbolic link or set timeouts: https://github.com/roblevintennis/yeoman_requirejs_template

Warning *shameless self promotion* ... check out this youtube vid on how require.js, mocha/expect.js/chai, etc. all work together if you're a beginner to those: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pYK6ymwAV1s
message:
Hey there Bill, very nice article - thanks for sharing. I've done the infamous BG kata in php and Java but I guess I'll have to try it out in JS huh!

So I've looked at getting the whole require.js thing working with yeoman and found that I was able to do this without either the symbolic link or set timeouts: https://github.com/roblevinten...

Warning *shameless self promotion* ... check out this youtube vid on how require.js, mocha/expect.js/chai, etc. all work together if you're a beginner to those: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v...

raw_message: Note that (at least with the current version of express) to route an HTTP delete call you use app.del("URL", function) NOT app.delete("URL", function) as the code examples above say. 'delete' is a reserved word in JavaScript.
message: Note that (at least with the current version of express) to route an HTTP delete call you use app.del("URL", function) NOT app.delete("URL", function) as the code examples above say. 'delete' is a reserved word in JavaScript.

Just wanted to say big *THANKS* for this amazing post and the videos. It's just what I was looking for :)

I'm wondering, though, if there is any way to run the tests right on the shell with a straightforward node "mocha" command, rather than using Yeoman's headless web runner. message:
Just wanted to say big *THANKS* for this amazing post and the videos. It's just what I was looking for :)

I'm wondering, though, if there is any way to run the tests right on the shell with a straightforward node "mocha" command, rather than using Yeoman's headless web runner. It seems to me that the workflow would be faster and more "flowy" if you didn't need to wait that second or so for Phantom.js and the mocha web runner...

raw_message:
Hi. Have you tested this code in IE7? I know it's time to move on but i can't even sleep knowing that has some people accessing one of my projects and been frustated by a feature that doesn't work.

Seems that the problem is in this part "collection.deferred.resolve();" and i can't figure out how to fix this. If i just fetch the collection and render the view, works in this browser, but  in the others don't. I'm learning the Backbone and i can't see how to deal with this problem.
message:

raw_message:
Nice post, thank you!

Some months ago I developed a RESTful application like this. But later on - the more resources it served, the more boring it became to write code. So I decided to write RESTful framework that simplifies developing such things.

Meet: https://github.com/jsmarkus/colibri

It is still under development, but new parts of my application are written with it. And I believe the Colibri project will grow, because it is not a just-for-fun thing.

I encourage you guys to join me in open-source development of Colibri framework :)
message:

Meet: https://github.com/jsmarkus/co...

It is still under development, but new parts of my application are written with it. And I believe the Colibri project will grow, because it is not a just-for-fun thing.

I encourage you guys to join me in open-source development of Colibri framework :)

raw_message: John the online book "Backbone Fundamentals" has some tips on using jQuery Mobile with Backbone. `$.mobile.hashListeningEnabled = false;` allows you to use Backbone's router not jQuery Mobile routing. Also when dynamically inserting dom elements in Backbone view objects' render methods you can use `this.$el.html(markup).trigger("create")` the create event tells jQuery mobile to decorate the markup its framework, so your markup can can include html5 data- attribute that jQuery mobile uses to handle the display of the new dom element you introduce with Backbone views.
message: John the online book "Backbone Fundamentals" has some tips on using jQuery Mobile with Backbone. `$.mobile.hashListeningEnabled = false;` allows you to use Backbone's router not jQuery Mobile routing. Also when dynamically inserting dom elements in Backbone view objects' render methods you can use `this.$el.html(markup).trigger("create")` the create event tells jQuery mobile to decorate the markup its framework, so your markup can can include html5 data- attribute that jQuery mobile uses to handle the display of the new dom element you introduce with Backbone views.

raw_message:
I updated this post adding the code to app.js for the bulk actions for UPDATE and DELETE. Also added to the gist code a fixtures.js file to use to create products following a bulk delete, and a bulk-updates.js script to for AJAX PUT request to update multiple products.

Also added to the gist is Backbone.js code to render a list of the products using this API, see: https://gist.github.com/1791080#file_frontend.html
